awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Face Analyzer / Semantic Search
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is significant as the company’s advanced Face Analysis AI technology will accelerate AI projects by 18-24 months. This innovative technology is poised to have a positive influence on various sectors such as retail and public safety, offering applications that go beyond facial recognition/identification. By focusing on collaborative human-AI facial tracking and analysis, this technology addresses ethical concerns and mitigates the risks and consequences of traditional facial recognition technologies. The project promotes diversity and inclusion in STEM fields by emphasizing a diverse team to combat bias and equity issues in technology development. The technology can contribute to national defense efforts by enabling efficient search for facial attributes of interest based on semantic queries. This aspect is particularly relevant in public safety scenarios with large crowds and high-security concerns. By reducing bias, improving accuracy, and addressing privacy and ethical concerns, the technology can have a lasting impact on the AI industry while advancing the welfare of the American public and supporting security efforts.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to create Face Analyzer/Semantic Search, an AI system bridging descriptive text and facial photos. Unlike conventional face recognition systems, which necessitate a probe photo for comparisons, the company's innovation seeks to eliminate this requirement. This approach offers benefits in terms of time, cost, and accuracy, challenging the conventional wisdom in the field. The project's initial challenge involves assembling diverse training datasets with labeled face photos and textual descriptions, establishing a scalable data pipeline to enhance accuracy and mitigate bias. The second challenge is assessing the accuracy of facial attribute classification models derived from text and images across various attributes, image types, sizes, and ambient conditions. The third challenge involves optimizing model size and computational efficiency for cost-effective deployment. The proposed solution entails constructing a comprehensive training image dataset, expanding computer vision capabilities, developing a natural language processing module, and implementing a matching system. Key milestones for product development include creating precise facial image indexing modules, enabling the extraction of facial attributes from textual descriptions, and efficiently deploying the system in the cloud. The innovation promises to streamline and enhance facial analysis, potentially reshaping the field of face AI.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Disclaimer: This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

For this project, AlgoFace, Inc. advances the field of AI-driven facial analysis by introducing a semantic search-based facial attribute retrieval system that does not rely on traditional face recognition techniques. Unlike existing solutions that require direct image comparison, AlgoFace’s system integrates computer vision and natural language processing (NLP) models to match textual descriptions with visual facial attributes. This patented technology could be employed across digital image databases to find persons of interest without knowing their identity or having a reference photo of them, as is required for facial recognition. Follow-on research from this project will develop similar face analysis technology across digital video databases and live camera networks. While the technology for this project can be employed across image databases for several industries, a key focus for AlgoFace is to assist law enforcement and public safety use-cases.  For example, with this technology, police can interview a crime victim who does not know their assailant to get a plain language description of the suspect, and rapidly search existing mugshot image databases to find potential suspects or images of people who look like the suspects - using the technology like a “digital sketch artist” for initial analysis and investigation. Or, once the technology can be employed across live camera networks in the future, a description of a person of interest - such as a criminal, a lost child or an elder patient with a mental disability - could be searched for across the camera networks of large public facilities such as airports, mass transit hubs, or other public spaces, using the semantic search-based facial attribute retrieval system to locate them real-time. 

Utilizing multiple AlgoFace patents, a novel semantic search-based facial attribute retrieval system has been developed allowing users to search for a robust number of facial attributes within images in a database using natural language description search terms. After a query is made, ranked results are then displayed based on closest matches. Various challenges were addressed and overcome, including: assembling diverse training datasets with labeled photos and textual descriptions that enhance accuracy and mitigate bias; assessing the accuracy of facial attribute classification models derived from text and images across various attributes, image types, sizes, and ambient condition variables; and optimizing model size and computational efficiency for effective deployment.    

This technology advances the safety and welfare of the American public by providing law enforcement, public safety, and national defense organizations with a valuable and ethically responsible face AI tool. The company’s team, broadly and for this project, also consists of individuals from diverse backgrounds, whose lived experiences and perspectives helped inform the development of this technology, focused on the importance of mitigating bias in modeling and enhancing the accuracy of results. AlgoFace’s technology reduces legal, privacy, and ethical risks associated with facial recognition and privacy while still focusing on speed and utility. 

Initial feedback from prospective customers and stakeholders during this project indicates a strong interest in the technology as a useful tool for criminal investigation and prevention, and for enhancing public safety. Numerous police departments and law enforcement experts, as well as security experts with experience in major government agencies and large public venues, were interviewed and expressed interest in these efforts. It is their opinion that the commercialization of face analysis semantic search technologies will not only lead to major opportunities in these industries, but also allow enforcement officers to be more efficient and effective in making their communities and visitors safer. Many see it as a complement to other investigative technologies that could potentially save time to solve crimes or address public safety issues more quickly, efficiently, and ultimately, make the public communities that they serve safer. 


 


Last Modified: 02/15/2025
Modified by: Taleb Alashkar
